data.source: Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM); Flash Eurobarometer Survey on Entrepreneurship (FESE); U.S. Census Bureau International Data Base (IDB) for demographics
data.wave_or_subset: GEM 2001–2010; FESE 2002, 2003, 2004, 2007, 2009; analyses by OECD vs. non-OECD; ages 15–60
data.sample_size: GEM: over 1.3 million individuals aged 15–60 across 82 countries; country-year observations ≈ 393 overall (≈ 230 for OECD subsample). FESE: OECD countries (16–21 countries per year depending on wave).
data.unit_of_analysis: Country-year (core); country–age–year cells; individual-level survey responses aggregated to country(-age)-year
data.notes: Entrepreneurship defined using multiple measures (e.g., early-stage, wage-paying vs. regardless of wage); population weights applied; standard errors clustered at the country level; demographic structure summarized by cohort shrinkage parameter r; GEM-FESE entrepreneurship rates moderately correlated (r = 0.50).

method.description: The study develops a theoretical model linking demographic age structure to entrepreneurship (rank effect) and tests its predictions using cross-country panel regressions based on GEM (and FESE) survey data combined with demographic statistics from the IDB. Empirical analyses regress country(-age)-year entrepreneurship rates on demographic measures (median age, cohort shrinkage parameter r, share younger than a), include standard macro controls, use year dummies, cluster standard errors at the country level, and perform robustness checks across definitions of entrepreneurship and OECD vs. non-OECD samples.
steps: Construct demographic measures for each country-year from IDB (median age; cohort shrinkage parameter r; shares younger than given ages).
Compute entrepreneurship rates from GEM (and FESE) under multiple definitions (e.g., early-stage paying wages; early-stage regardless of wages).

Assemble country-year and country–age–year panels; apply population weights; add macro controls (log GDP per capita, GDP growth, agriculture share, education rates, startup costs, property rights indices, military service duration).

Estimate reduced-form OLS regressions of entrepreneurship rates on demographic variables with year dummies and country-clustered standard errors; conduct specifications using r, median age, age and age-squared, and share-younger-than-age.
Run subset analyses (OECD vs. non-OECD) and robustness checks including alternative entrepreneurship definitions and fixed-effects variants where applicable.
Interpret coefficients to assess the rank effect and the inverted-U relationship with age; compare GEM and FESE results for consistency.
method.models: Reduced-form OLS regressions with year fixed effects and country-clustered standard errors; specifications include age and age-squared (inverted-U), demographic structure parameter r, median age, and share of population younger than age a; some fixed-effects checks.
method.outcome_variable: Entrepreneurship rate (primarily early-stage businesses that pay wages) at the country-year and age-specific country–age–year levels; alternative definitions also examined.
method.independent_variables: Demographic structure parameter r; median age; share of population younger than age a; age and age-squared; macro controls (log GDP per capita, GDP growth, agriculture share, education rates, startup costs, property rights index, military service duration).
method.control_variables: Log GDP per capita; GDP growth; agriculture share of GDP; education rates; startup costs; property rights index; military service duration; year dummies; (fixed effects in some checks).

results.summary: Younger demographic structures are associated with higher entrepreneurship rates. A one standard deviation decrease in median age corresponds to a 2.5 percentage point increase in business formation (about 40% of the mean rate). The demographic structure parameter r is strongly negatively related to entrepreneurship (e.g., coefficient around −2.041, p < 0.001). Entrepreneurship exhibits an inverted-U relationship with age, peaking in the early 30s. These patterns are robust across alternative entrepreneurship definitions, OECD vs. non-OECD samples, and complementary FESE data. Predicted rates illustrate sizable cross-country differences linked to age structure (e.g., Japan vs. U.S.).
